message_text: Paper Title: Fixed-Time and Prescribed-Time Consensus Control of Multiagent Systems and Its Applications: A Survey of Recent Trends and Methodologies Paper Abstract: Fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control can bring an explicit estimate of the settling time without dependence on initial conditions, which is important in providing control engineers a priori system information. This article aims at presenting a survey of recent trends and methodologies of fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control in multiagent systems. First, some typical fixed-time consensus results are reviewed. Despite the advantage in deriving a fixed settling time bound, fixed-time consensus controllers usually result in a conservative estimate of the bound and a large magnitude of initial control input, which in turn show the necessity of designing prescribed-time consensus controllers. Second, characteristics and controller design of (practical, respectively) prescribed-time consensus are provided in detail. Particularly, representative time-varying function-based controllers are presented, by which (practical, respectively) consensus can be achieved in prescribed time. Third, applications of fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control in mobile robots and smart grids are illustrated in case studies. Finally, several challenging issues in prescribed-time consensus control are discussed for future research. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

## Search Results for "Multiagent Systems"

I found comprehensive information about multiagent systems. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Core Concept

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important features including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

### Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications and Related Fields

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling. Additionally, multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

### Research and Community

The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of distributed algorithms:

## Definition

A distributed algorithm is an algorithm designed to run on computer hardware constructed from interconnected processors.

## Applications

Distributed algorithms are used in different application areas of distributed computing, such as telecommunications, scientific computing, distributed information processing, and real-time process control.

## Common Problems and Solutions

Standard problems solved by distributed algorithms include leader election, consensus, distributed search, spanning tree generation, mutual exclusion, and resource allocation. For example, common algorithms for solving consensus are the Paxos algorithm and the Raft algorithm.

## Key Characteristics

Distributed algorithms are a sub-type of parallel algorithm, typically executed concurrently, with separate parts of the algorithm being run simultaneously on independent processors, and having limited information about what the other parts of the algorithm are doing.

## Major Challenges

One of the major challenges in developing and implementing distributed algorithms is successfully coordinating the behavior of the independent parts of the algorithm in the face of processor failures and unreliable communication.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of mobile robots:

## What Are Mobile Robots?

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.

## Key Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots have diverse uses across multiple sectors:

- **Healthcare**: Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- **Warehousing**: Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- **Industrial Settings**: Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

## Navigation Evolution

Current commercial robots autonomously navigate based on sensing natural features. The first commercial robots to achieve this were Pyxus' HelpMate hospital robot and the CyberMotion guard robot, both designed by robotics pioneers in the 1980s.

Web search results for query: "consensus control"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:What is consensus? - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:What_is_consensus"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_democracy"},{"title":"Cultural consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_consensus_theory"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Knowledge regime - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_regime"}]

Based on the search results, "consensus control" refers to several related concepts depending on the context:

## In Systems and Multi-Agent Control

Consensus control (also known as consensus dynamics or agreement dynamics) is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)In multi-agent systems, the consensus problem involves ensuring that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)Consensus control has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## In Computer Science and Distributed Systems

In distributed computing, the consensus problem is a fundamental problem in controlling multi-agent systems.(no content)It involves coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.(no content)Real-world applications include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs, load balancing, and blockchain.

## Broader Meanings

The term "consensus control" can also relate to consensus decision-making, which is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve broad acceptance.

Here's a comprehensive overview of smart grids based on the search results:

## Definition

A smart grid is most commonly defined as an electric grid that has been digitized to enable two way communication between producers and consumers.(no content)The smart grid is an enhancement of the 20th century electrical grid, using two-way communications and distributed so-called intelligent devices.

## Objectives and Benefits

The objective of the smart grid is to update electricity infrastructure to include more advanced communication, control, and sensory technology with the hope of increasing communication between consumers and energy producers.(no content)The potential benefits from a smart grid include increased reliability, more efficient electricity use, better economics, and improved sustainability.

## Key Technologies and Features

Research is mainly focused on three systems of a smart grid – the infrastructure system, the management system, and the protection system. ## Historical Development

The concept of a smart grid began to emerge in the early 2000s.(no content)Key federal legislation driving the development of smart grid-related technology for the American electrical system includes Title XIII of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (EISA).

## Global Implementation

Many countries have been pursuing a smart grid, with each country having their own unique definition of a smart grid based on their own policies and objectives, and therefore every country approaches achieving a smart grid a little different.

Web search results for query: "control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Systems control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_control"},{"title":"Systems and Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_and_Control"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Category:Air pollution control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Air_pollution_control_systems"},{"title":"Industrial process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_process_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Smoke control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoke_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"}]

## Search Results for "Control Systems"

Here's an overview of control systems based on the search results:

### General Definition

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems which are used for controlling processes.

### Types of Control Systems

**Closed-Loop vs. Open-Loop:**
A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

**Common Types:**
- An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

- On–off control uses a feedback controller that switches abruptly between two states. A simple bi-metallic domestic thermostat can be described as an on-off controller.

### Industrial Applications

An industrial control system (ICS) is an electronic control system and associated instrumentation used for industrial process control.(no content)Larger systems are usually implemented by supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, or DCSs, and programmable logic controllers (PLCs), though SCADA and PLC systems are scalable down to small systems with few control loops.

Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** SURVEY - This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent trends and methodologies in fixed-time and prescribed-time consensus control for multiagent systems.

**Triples Generated:** 6 key entities identified and mapped to Wikipedia articles:

1. **Consensus dynamics** (concept) - Reviews consensus control methods enabling multiagent agreement
2. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Core subject of control and coordination in autonomous agent systems
3. **Control system** (method) - Foundational control theory framework for consensus methods
4. **Mobile robot** (task) - Primary application domain discussed in case studies
5. **Smart grid** (task) - Major application domain for distributed power grid coordination
6. **Distributed algorithm** (method) - Theoretical foundation for achieving consensus through distributed computation

**Validation:** ✅ All validation checks passed successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, relations, and relevance descriptions.

The analysis correctly identifies this as a survey paper (not a contribution) with appropriate "uses" relations for all triples, as the paper builds upon and reviews existing methodologies rather than proposing entirely novel approaches.
